articles.headline: Breaking the Silence
articles.snippet: The shifting nature of wealth and inheritance has families talking — about values as well as money.
articles.abstract: The shifting nature of wealth and inheritance has families talking — about values as well as money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dal LaMagna, founder of the Tweezerman company, considered how to leave his wealth to his two children, he thought back to his early 30s, just before he achieved success. At the time, said Mr. LaMagna, 61, “I thought if I could get 600 bucks a week, I could retire on that, and I would be very happy.”

articles.headline: Online Games by the Hundreds, With Tie-Ins
articles.snippet: By entering the online-game sector, media companies can attract advertising, including from food companies that have agreed to limit the nature and volume of television ads aimed at children.
articles.abstract: By entering the online-game sector, media companies can attract advertising, including from food companies that have agreed to limit the nature and volume of television ads aimed at children.
articles.lead_paragraph: For some children, watching “Dora the Explorer” on television is becoming passé. Now, they want to be Dora.

articles.headline: Bush Backs Fed’s Actions, but Critics Quickly Find Fault
articles.snippet: The White House faced accusations that it is helping a corporate giant but doing little to aid people facing foreclosure.
articles.abstract: The White House faced accusations that it is helping a corporate giant but doing little to aid people facing foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Monday welcomed the Federal Reserve’s sweeping intervention in the nation’s financial markets as his administration faced accusations that it had supported the bailout of a prestigious investment bank while doing little to address the hardships of Americans facing foreclosures on their homes.

articles.headline: Rallying the House of Morgan
articles.snippet: James Dimon, as head of JP Morgan Chase, has suddenly become the most talked about, and arguably the most powerful, banker in the world today.
articles.abstract: James Dimon, as head of JP Morgan Chase, has suddenly become the most talked about, and arguably the most powerful, banker in the world today.
articles.lead_paragraph: High in a Park Avenue skyscraper, within a maze of soft rugs and wood-paneled walls, James Dimon sits just footsteps from the mahogany roll-top desk of J. Pierpont Morgan, the feared lord of the House of Morgan and the most powerful financier of his time.

articles.headline: Saving Wall St. (for Now)
articles.snippet: Bear Stearns’s downfall and subsequent sale to JPMorgan Chase on Sunday was orchestrated by some of the most powerful people on Wall Street and in Washington.
articles.abstract: Bear Stearns’s downfall and subsequent sale to JPMorgan Chase on Sunday was orchestrated by some of the most powerful people on Wall Street and in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: The whispers began on Wednesday, and by Sunday it was all over.

articles.headline: At Lehman, Allaying Fears About Being the Next to Fall
articles.snippet: Since the mortgage market crisis unfolded in the summer, investors have fretted that Lehman will stumble, and its stock has fallen from a peak of $82 a share then.
articles.abstract: Since the mortgage market crisis unfolded in the summer, investors have fretted that Lehman will stumble, and its stock has fallen from a peak of $82 a share then.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shocked by the rapid demise of Bear Stearns and its fire sale to JPMorgan Chase, investors sold off the stock of Lehman Brothers and several other financial firms Monday.

articles.headline: Plunge Averted, Markets Look Ahead Uneasily
articles.snippet: Nervousness pervaded Wall Street despite the efforts by the Federal Reserve to restore order within the financial system.
articles.abstract: Nervousness pervaded Wall Street despite the efforts by the Federal Reserve to restore order within the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Dow Jones industrial average up slightly more than 21 points by the end of trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, it may have looked like a calm day on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Rescue Tests the Fed’s Credibility
articles.snippet: The Fed is putting its reputation and resources on the line to rescue Wall Street’s biggest institutions from their mistakes.
articles.abstract: The Fed is putting its reputation and resources on the line to rescue Wall Street’s biggest institutions from their mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Far more than at any time before, the Federal Reserve is putting its vast resources and its reputation on the line to rescue Wall Street’s biggest institutions from their far-reaching mistakes.

articles.headline: Aftershocks of a Collapse, With a Bank at the Epicenter
articles.snippet: For employees of Bear Stearns, many of whom have spent most of their professional lives at Bear, the sudden collapse was unfathomable.
articles.abstract: For employees of Bear Stearns, many of whom have spent most of their professional lives at Bear, the sudden collapse was unfathomable.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shouts, hoarse and high-pitched, rang out in the cavernous boardroom late Sunday at Bear Stearns’s headquarters on Madison Avenue. Alan D. Schwartz, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, was briefing top executives on the deal he had just struck under duress with JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York: their stock in Bear was now worth $2 a share.

articles.headline: On Defensive, Obama Plans Talk on Race
articles.snippet: Facing a major test, Barack Obama was writing a speech aides said could be one of the most crucial of his campaign.
articles.abstract: Facing a major test, Barack Obama was writing a speech aides said could be one of the most crucial of his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with what his advisers acknowledged was a major test to his candidacy, Senator Barack Obama sought on Monday to contain the damage from incendiary comments made by his pastor and prepared to address the issue of race more directly than at any other moment of his presidential campaign.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Simmering Resentments Led to Tibetan Backlash
articles.snippet: The only surprising thing about unrest in Tibet may be that Beijing managed to keep things stable for so long.
articles.abstract: The only surprising thing about unrest in Tibet may be that Beijing managed to keep things stable for so long.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Chinese leaders have blamed “splittists” led by the exiled Dalai Lama for spurring violent protests in Tibet and orchestrating a public relations sneak attack on the Communist Party, as they gear up to play host to the Olympics Games this summer.
